body:
One of my users of my cython library is running into the following issue https://github.com/maxbachmann/RapidFuzz/issues/95:

He has the following program
```
from flask import Flask, Response
from rapidfuzz import process

app = application = Flask(__name__)

class HelloWorld:
    @classmethod
    def on_get(cls):
        return Response('\r\n', mimetype='application/json')

app.add_url_rule('/', '/', view_func=HelloWorld.on_get)
```

which he starts using
```gunicorn --bind 0.0.0.0:8080 --worker-class gevent --workers 4 --threads 2 testapp```

When importing rapidfuzz there is a segmentation fault
```
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668047] [INFO] Starting gunicorn 20.1.0
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668047] [INFO] Listening at: http://0.0.0.0:8080 (668047)
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668047] [INFO] Using worker: gevent
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668048] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 668048
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668049] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 668049
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668050] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 668050
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668051] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 668051
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668047] [WARNING] Worker with pid 668048 was terminated due to signal 11
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668060] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 668060
[2021-03-29 21:27:16 +0200] [668047] [WARNING] Worker with pid 668049 was terminated due to signal 11
```

I am using the latest master version to generate the C++ code used in my library. It appears, that this error occurs since the following commit: https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/65bbb6f295718f09108c8649ba3ce98318e65816. The issue does not occur when directly importing the library in Python.

comment_data.body: Which Python version are you using? 3.9? Could you try it with earlier ones to see if that makes a difference?
I could reproduce the error both in Python3.9 and Python3.5 on Linux (Fedora).
Hmm … could this be a bug in gunicorn? Maybe it mishandles Cython compiled coroutines?

Note that the change in 65bbb6f295718f09108c8649ba3ce98318e65816 intentionally only impacts `asyncio.iscoroutinefunction()` and not `inspect.iscouroutinefunction()`. Maybe gunicorn confuses the two.

Update: I couldn't find such a call in the sources. Needs some deeper investigation.

As suggested by @da-woods I used
```python
faulthandler.enable(file=sys.stderr, all_threads=True)
```

This outputs the following stacktrace:
```
Current thread 0x00007f8df2619740 (most recent call first):
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 222 in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 945 in exec_module

  File "/home/max/RapidFuzz/flask2.py", line 7 in <module>
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 222 in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 697 in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 673 in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 957 in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 968 in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 985 in _gcd_import
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.5/importlib/__init__.py", line 126 in import_module
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/util.py", line 359 in import_app
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/wsgiapp.py", line 48 in load_wsgiapp
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/wsgiapp.py", line 58 in load
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/base.py", line 67 in wsgi
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/workers/base.py", line 146 in load_wsgi
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/workers/base.py", line 134 in init_process
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/workers/ggevent.py", line 146 in init_process
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/arbiter.py", line 589 in spawn_worker
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/arbiter.py", line 622 in spawn_workers
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/arbiter.py", line 551 in manage_workers
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/arbiter.py", line 211 in run
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/base.py", line 72 in run
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/base.py", line 231 in run
  File "/home/max/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/gunicorn/app/wsgiapp.py", line 67 in run
  File "/home/max/.local/bin/gunicorn", line 8 in <module>
Fatal Python error: Segmentation fault
```
Ok, so the crash is somewhere in `cpp_process.pyx`. Not very informative, I guess.
yes normalways I would just run it with gdb and check the backtrace, but I do not really understand how to do this when using gunicorn, which simple restarts after a segmentation fault.

This is the backtrace printed by `catchsegv`

```

```
… and now rebuild your module with `CFLAGS="-O0 -ggdb"` to get function names in the stack trace.

This did not really help. With "-O0 -ggdb" the only difference is
```
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0xfdb9a)[0x7f6e96490b9a]
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0x12d930)[0x7f6e964c0930]
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0x12dfe4)[0x7f6e964c0fe4]
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0x124fdf)[0x7f6e964b7fdf]
```
instead of
```
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0x3484c)[0x7fc7753de84c]
/home/max/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/rapidfuzz/cpp_process.cpython-39-x86_64-linux-gnu.so(+0x1e4b9)[0x7fc7753c84b9]
```
which I assume simply means, that it inlined less with `-O0`
Yeah … all this really tells us is that it happens while executing your main module code, i.e. while importing your module. :-/
What happens if you use only one thread per gunicorn instance?

```
gunicorn --bind 0.0.0.0:8080 --worker-class gevent --workers 1 --threads 1 flask2
```
fails with the same error
The error already occurs when I only add `func_is_coroutine` to `__pyx_CyFunctionObject`

Ah – but you said that you're using Cython master, right? Then that's the issue here. gevent also uses Cython, but probably alpha-6, which doesn't have that field yet. The two modules are simply binary incompatible. Try with alpha-6 instead. Or build both packages with the master branch. Or change the version number of your local Cython installation in `Cython/Shadow.py`.
Ah yes that is definetly the issue. Does the version number has to follow a specific scheme? or can I simply use something like `3.0a7-devel`?
It's just a name, but it's used in C code (maybe mangled?). Underscores should work.
I just tried. It tries to parse `7_devel` as an int and fails. I guess I will simply go with `3.0a0` which will never be released
Fixed this in https://github.com/maxbachmann/RapidFuzz/releases/tag/v1.4.1. Thank you for your assistance @scoder.

title: [BUG] segmentation fault on module import
